name: dedth
params: class c0, class c1, wff w0, wff w1, wff w2
body: -| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))

stmt.origin: syl(w0, wb(w1, w2), wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)))

body.origin:
|- wi(w0, wb(w1, w2))
-| wi(w0, wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)))
-| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))

cumulated.origin:
|- wi(w0, w1)
-| w2
-| wi(w0, wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)))
-| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))

body.origin:
|- wi(w0, wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)))
-| wi(w0, wceq(cif(c0, c1, w0), c0))

cumulated.origin:
|- wi(w0, w1)
-| w2
-| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))
-| wi(w0, wceq(cif(c0, c1, w0), c0))

|- wi(w0, w1)
-| w2
-| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))

comment: Weak deduction theorem that eliminates a hypothesis ` ph ` , making it become an antecedent. We assume that a proof exists for ` ph ` when the class variable ` A ` is replaced with a specific class ` B ` . The hypothesis ` ch ` should be assigned to the inference, and the inference hypothesis eliminated with ~ elimhyp . If the inference has other hypotheses with class variable ` A ` , these can be kept by assigning ~ keephyp to them. For more information, see the Weak Deduction Theorem page ~ mmdeduction.html . (Contributed by NM, 15-May-1999.)
